Hi,

I noticed that the migrations fails on sqlite. The problem is linked to the fact that SQL Lite does not support alter tables and I have to use a batch alter instead:

```
    with op.batch_alter_table('columns') as batch_op:
        batch_op.drop_constraint('columns_ibfk_1', type_="foreignkey")
        batch_op.create_foreign_key('columns_ibfk_1', 'datasources', ['datasource_name'], ['datasource_name'])
```

The problem with this approach is that the sqlite schema doesn't have a name on the foreign key so there's no way I could drop it.

Reference also #516.

As I suggested in my issue, there should be a configuration flag or the function should detect the druid version to decide how to perform the query.

Assuming that everyone is using the last version of druid is a mistake. Druid is used in production in clusters of several servers. Upgrading such an installation is difficult and requires downtime.
@LAlbertalli it would be cool to have all the description you write in pull requests in the git commit messages too :)
@LAlbertalli since sqlite is the default db please add the batch context manager to keep caravel working out of the box.
@xrmx Git Amended the commit message to insert the description of the error

@kkalyan Your approach is sensible but I wonder whether it could break someone's installation.

In general, I agree with your approach that the default behavior should be the correct one, not a work around. But in this specific situation, this could cause some issue. I'd like to see what other thinks.

I am facing the EXACT same error while refreshing druid metadata. Are we pushing this fix to prod?

Thank you so much @mtrbean !
Now it's working!
The constraint issue is mentioned here: #466 , but I can't get any response

@xrmx Seems like it only works when you have created the foreign keys with naming_convention specified. But it's too late now, for those who has been using mysql, the foreign keys have been named according to the default name convention of MySQL. The only solution I have figured out so far is to try on every kind of databases and try to drop the key by trying through each of the default foreign key names.
For me https://github.com/airbnb/caravel/pull/531/files fixed the issue

@xrmx @x4base I see two options moving forward. Modifying the init migration to fix the error. I'm not happy with that but it should solve the issue for new install. People who are already using it, or they don't check foreign keys, or they have already fixed it.

The second option, that I actually like more, is to surround the migration with an exception handling code to skip sqlite and find the correct name for PGSQL.

To be honest, I will go for both actions (change init and use error handling) to cover all the possible issues.

Let me know what do you prefer. It will take me probably few days to provide the patch.

Bye
L.
Yes, because it is specialized for MySQL and will only work on MySQL. You can try it on SQLite or other databases. It won't work because the foreign key is not named that way
That's why I said I want a "universal migration script that works on every SQL dialects"

I agree with droping the key by the pgsql. But i am concerned about whether we should cover more Sql dialects (e.g. mssql) that sqlalchemy supports or should we just assume that no one is using other dialects?

@x4base I was thinking of sqlite, MySQL, and pg because they are the databases listed in https://github.com/airbnb/caravel/blob/master/caravel/config.py#L35 as an example. But, yes, nothing forbid to use MS SQL or Oracle. If someone has ideas...

Revisiting config option, I think adding config at caravel level is not a good idea, as caravel may be used to work with different versions of Druid. 
There should a field (version no) added at each Druid Cluster, since this more involved change, I'll wait till one of the commiters respond.

I've taken a different approach and started a native backend.

WIP is at https://github.com/sathieu/caravel/tree/elasticsearch (beware: I'll squash commits and force push).

Not much is working yet, and I don't have dedicated time on it. We'll see what comes.
I agree with the approach of adding a version field to the DruidCluster model and hard coding logic based on it.
Oh interesting, we use presto and the current auto-cast works for us. What version of presto are you using?

The last commit should work for every supported DB.

I've tested it against sqlite and partially tested against MySQL and it worked both upgrade and downgrade.

The "magic" is done by a function that uses the sqlalchemy reflection capability to detect the correct constraint name.

Is b4456560d4f3 the last version in the db history?
I encountered similar problem once: the migration is actually applied to the db, but the version number in  table "alembic_version" in the database is not updated to the newest one. 
Is your problem the same as mine?

No, there are other migrations after this one that are correctly applied.
As I mentioned, it seems to suffer from the same problem of commit #531. They simply put a try/except to make it work on sqlite, but this swallow errors on every other db when the migration is wrongly written.

I found an easy fix for this issue, which is setting the PYTHONIOENCODING environment variable to UTF-8 (otherwise, python thinks it can't send UTF8 characters to the terminal)
In docker, this can be done with -e PYTHONIOENCODING=UTF-8
